The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that cause diseases in a wide range of hosts. The evolutionary origin of this group has been elusive, but a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies. Here, we present a comparative analysis of the genomes of two myxozoans and a cnidarian parasite. Our results suggest that the transition from a free-living cnidarian to a parasitic myxozoan was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. This study provides insight into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite. (Show more)

The ability of the immune system to recognize and eliminate pathogens is a key factor in the survival of the host. In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to block the nuclear translocation of STAT1 and STAT2, two key transcription factors that are essential for the induction of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs). We found that the SARS-CoV-2 accessory protein Orf6 is responsible for this activity and that it does so by interfering with the nuclear import of ISGs. Our results provide a mechanism of viral antagonism that is likely to be shared by other viruses. (Show more)

Voltage-gated proton (Hv1) channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. Sperm cells are quiescent in the male reproductive system due to Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1 channels, but become active once introduced into the low-Zn2+-concentration environment of the female reproductive tract. How Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 is not completely understood. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1 dimer. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. Climate change is expected to increase the variability of crop yields, making it more difficult for farmers to plan their crop production. This study shows that the variability of maize yields will increase substantially in the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries under 2 °C and 4 °C of global warming. This increase in variability will have severe consequences for food security, especially for the 800 million people living in extreme poverty. The results underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level diet. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant African LMH species. These species ranged from almost-exclusive grazers to almost-exclusive browsers, and grass consumption ranged from >99% to <1%. Grass consumption was highly correlated with isotopic estimates of grass consumption, indicating that RRA conveys reliable quantitative information about consumption. Dietary overlap was greatest between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption, but dietary composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on small businesses. We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses to understand the impact of the pandemic on their operations and finances. We find that many small businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Many businesses are financially fragile, and the majority plan to seek funding through the CARES Act. However, many anticipate problems with accessing the program, such as bureaucratic hassles and difficulties establishing eligibility.

Plastic debris is one of the most visible consequences of human activities in the ocean. However, the magnitude of the problem is still unknown. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This is due to the selective removal of the smallest particles by a combination of processes that are yet to be discovered. This study provides a first estimate of the global load of floating plastic debris, which is of fundamental importance to understand the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

Interstellar grains are the only direct evidence of the early solar system. We determined the ages of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The grains have ages of 3.9 ± 1.6 Ma to ∼3 ± 2 Ga before the start of the Solar System ∼4.6 Ga ago. A majority of the grains have interstellar lifetimes of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. We conclude that the grains condensed in outflows of asymptotic giant branch stars <4.9 Ga ago that possibly formed during an episode of enhanced star formation ∼7 Ga ago. The grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. The grains are the only evidence for the existence of the early active sun.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the number of motorized vessels has increased by a factor of 10. The expansion of the motorized fleet has been driven by the powered-artisanal fleet, which has grown by a factor of 10 since 1950. The powered-artisanal fleet is the most numerous and the most important in terms of engine power, but it contributes only 27% of the global engine power. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased by a factor of five since 1950, and the effective CPUE of the global fleet has decreased by a factor of two. In this study, we show that the increase in reproductive output that comes with domestication and allonursing is due to an increase in metabolic power rather than an increase in resource availability. We also show that the increase in reproductive output is due to an increase in the number of offspring rather than an increase in the size of each offspring. This suggests that the ultimate factor limiting reproductive output in placental mammals is maternal metabolic power rather than resource availability. Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the substantia nigra. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in oligodendrocytes, the cells that produce myelin in the central nervous system. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which is well tolerated in humans, is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in a mouse model of MSA. This effect is associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn, which is the main form of α-syn that is toxic to oligodendrocytes. Our results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate for the treatment of MSA.

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the most abundant cell type in the body. It is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between blood and tissue. The endothelium is also responsible for controlling the contractility of blood vessels, hemostasis, and inflammation. The endothelium is a highly specialized cell type that is able to control its function by receiving and integrating information from multiple sources. This information is received by a network of cells that are connected in a way that allows for the rapid and efficient transmission of information. This study reveals the nature of the communication network that the endothelium uses to control its function. The findings provide insight into the nature of the communication network and the design of the endothelium. This knowledge will be useful in understanding the endothelium and its role in cardiovascular health. It will also be useful in developing new therapies for cardiovascular disease.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. We describe the design and implementation of the COVIDcast API, a data source that provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 indicators, including many auxiliary indicators that are not available elsewhere. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. We hope that the COVIDcast API will be a valuable resource for researchers and decision makers.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion-channel family in the human body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological processes and are the target of a large number of drugs. The selectivity filter and the activation gate are functionally and structurally coupled. We have identified a key residue for this allosteric communication and have demonstrated that it is crucial for the allosteric coupling to be maintained during the opening of the channel.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is thought to be important for the health of the host. However, the role of the gut microbiome in health and disease is not fully understood. One of the main reasons for this is that the diversity of the gut microbiome is difficult to study, and the functions of the individual members of the microbiome are not well characterized. Here, we show that anaerobic fungi in the gut microbiome produce a large number of natural products, which could be used to study the role of the microbiome in health and disease.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, but the role of personality traits in the establishment of social hierarchy is poorly understood. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait, directly influences social dominance in male outbred rats and identify an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. High-anxious animals that are prone to become subordinate during a social encounter with a low-anxious rat exhibit reduced mitochondrial complex I and II proteins and respiratory capacity as well as decreased ATP and increased ROS production in the nucleus accumbens. A causal link for these findings is indicated by pharmacological approaches. In a dyadic contest between anxiety-matched animals, microinfusion of specific mitochondrial complex I or II inhibitors into the nucleus accumbens reduced social rank, mimicking the low probability to become dominant observed in high-anxious individuals. Conversely, intraaccumbal infusion of nicotinamide, an amide form of vitamin B3 known to enhance brain energy metabolism, prevented the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious individuals. We conclude that mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens is crucial for social hierarchy establishment and is critically involved in the low social competitiveness associated with high anxiety. The ability to design and manufacture multifunctional structures with desired mechanical responses is highly desired for a wide range of applications. However, the current design paradigm is limited by the availability of materials and the complexity of the structures. Here, we develop a synthesis strategy to discover optimal multimaterial structures that can precisely achieve arbitrary and extreme prescribed responses under large deformations. The structures are digitally synthesized and manufactured with different elastomers with distinct behaviors. The structures seamlessly collaborate through sophisticated deformation mechanisms to produce the target behaviors. The proposed strategy can be extended to design multifunctional structures with complex behaviors and navigability. The developed structures can be used for various applications, such as energy trapping, actuation, and sensing. This work provides a new paradigm for the design and manufacture of multifunctional structures with desired responses. (Show more)

Hemoglobin is the oxygen-carrying protein of red blood cells. The hemoglobin content of red blood cells is determined by the expression of two globin genes, alpha and beta, and the ratio of these two genes is the primary determinant of the hemoglobin content. In this study, we show that the expression of the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is developmentally regulated in human erythroid tissues and that IGF2BP1 can affect the expression of hemoglobin in human erythroid cells. These results suggest that IGF2BP1 may be a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of hemoglobinopathies.

Cancer is a leading cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we identified a mechanism of resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent peroxidation of phospholipids, in cancer cells. This mechanism involves sustained activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis, which, in turn, promotes sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1/stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1-mediated lipogenesis and resistance to oxidative stress. This mechanism can be overcome by targeting the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway in combination with ferroptosis induction. This approach may be useful for the treatment of cancer. (Show more)

Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure, and the treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of cardiovascular disease prevention. The most widely used drugs for treating hypertension are the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). However, the mechanisms of action of LCCBs are not fully understood. Here, we show that LCCBs activate a store-operated Ca2+ entry pathway in vascular smooth muscle cells, which is mediated by the Ca2+ channel Cav1.2 and the STIM Ca2+ sensor proteins. Our findings provide a mechanistic explanation for the association of LCCBs with heart failure and the need for caution in the use of LCCBs in patients with advanced hypertension and/or cardiovascular remodeling. This study also provides a rationale for the development of new drugs that target the LCCBs-induced Ca2+ signaling pathway. (Show more)

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP has not yet succeeded in reversing the decline of older-forest–associated bird species. Our findings highlight the need to continue to prioritize older forests and to ensure that the creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a long and expensive process, which is often unsuccessful. Here, we present a computational approach to accelerate the discovery of new antibiotics. We show that the design of acylide antibiotics can be achieved by a combination of molecular modeling and high-throughput screening. The best candidate is up to 56 times more active than telithromycin, a clinically used antibiotic, and is effective against antibiotic-resistant strains. This approach can be extended to the design of other classes of antibiotics.

Deep convolutional neural networks have been shown to be effective in many image-processing problems. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often large, and the network architecture is complex. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and a simple architecture. The proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The proposed architecture is also easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed architecture on several segmentation problems. The proposed architecture is expected to be useful in many image-processing problems. The code is available at this https URL .

The study of lake-level variability is a powerful tool for understanding the hydroclimate of the past. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate variability from Lake Malawi, East Africa. The results show that the lake level dropped dramatically during the Late Quaternary, resulting in a large-scale change in the landscape and ecosystem. We observe a dramatic shift at the MPT, consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after 800,000 years ago. The study of Lake Malawi provides a unique window into the past, allowing us to understand the impact of hydroclimate variability on the evolution of the cichlid fish species flock. The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. This study shows that this practice has important consequences for sleep. Participants who read an electronic book on a light-emitting device took longer to fall asleep and had reduced evening sleepiness, reduced melatonin secretion, later timing of their circadian clock, and reduced next-morning alertness than when reading a printed book. These results demonstrate that evening exposure to an electronic book phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a well-known event in the Holocene climate record. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the event. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the Os in the YDB samples is likely terrestrial in origin, and that the Os in the spherules is also likely terrestrial in origin. The Os in the spherules is likely derived from a source in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America. The role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity has been controversial. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is required for the development of autoimmunity, but its specific role in the development of autoimmunity is complex and depends on the type of autoimmunity.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We reconstructed the evolutionary history of beetles using a comprehensive dataset of 154 genomes and 4,818 genes. Our analyses resolved previously controversial beetle relationships, dated the origin of Coleoptera to the Carboniferous, and supported the codiversification of beetles and angiosperms. Moreover, plant cell wall-degrading enzymes (PCWDEs) obtained from bacteria and fungi via horizontal gene transfers may have been key to the Mesozoic diversification of herbivorous beetles—remarkably, both major independent origins of specialized herbivory in beetles coincide with the first appearances of an arsenal of PCWDEs encoded in their genomes. Beetle diversity thus appears to have resulted from multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding PCWDEs.

The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants has led to the development of new variants of concern (VOCs) that have shown increased transmissibility and immune evasion. This study demonstrates the use of a deep learning algorithm to improve the neutralizing activity of an antibody against SARS-CoV-2 variants. The algorithm can be used to identify changes in the CDR regions of an antibody that can improve its binding affinity to the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein. The optimized antibody can be used to develop an antibody drug candidate to treat COVID-19. This study provides a potential solution to the problem of SARS-CoV-2 variants and may be applicable to other emerging viral threats. (Simplified version available)

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of great interest to evolutionary psychologists. We report the results of a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that, contrary to popular belief, population size does not enhance CCE. Instead, it appears that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our findings have implications for the evolution of technology and the evolution of culture.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and the fifth leading cause of death in the United States. The strongest genetic risk factor for AD is the APOE4 allele. APOE is a protein that is produced by astrocytes, a type of glial cell. We report here a novel role for APOE in the rate of astrocytic phagocytosis of synapses, which is highly dependent on APOE isoform. We also suggest a hypothesis that APOE4 may be associated with AD risk because of the enhanced accumulation of senescent synapses in the brain. This hypothesis is supported by the finding that APOE4 increases the rate of C1q-mediated synapse degeneration. These studies reveal a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest a mechanism for the increased risk of AD associated with APOE4. This mechanism may be relevant to the development of new therapeutic strategies for AD.

The Earth's inner core is a solid sphere with a diameter of 2,300 km, which is the size of a small country. It is the only solid sphere in the universe. The inner core is a unique natural laboratory for studying the crystallization process of molten iron. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. We demonstrate that the bcc phase of iron is more stable than the hcp phase under the inner core conditions. This bcc nucleation is likely to be the first step of the inner core formation, which reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation and solves the inner core nucleation paradox. This study provides a new perspective for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the inner core. (Show more)

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the brain effects of marijuana are not well understood, the drug is known to increase the activity of the brain’s reward system, dopamine. Here, we show that the brain’s dopamine response to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine, is reduced in marijuana abusers. This reduced dopamine response is associated with increased irritability and addiction.

Language is a uniquely human skill, and the brain’s processing of language is a central focus of neuroscience. Here, we use a powerful new class of artificial neural networks to study language processing in the brain. We find that the most powerful models predict nearly 100% of the explainable variance in neural responses to sentences. These models also predict behavior on a critical task of language comprehension. We show that model architecture contributes to both neural and behavioral fit. These results provide computational evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the brain’s mechanisms of language comprehension. They also suggest that the language comprehension system in the human brain may be more similar to a modern computer program than we realized.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning, but it has been plagued by instability. We show that this instability is a consequence of the fact that DL is a special case of a more general problem, inverse problems, which are well-posed. We introduce a new class of neural networks, fast iterative restarted networks (FIRENETs), which are stable and can be trained in a small number of iterations. We prove that only O(|log (ϵ)|) layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem. Our results provide a classification theory for the existence of algorithms that compute stable NNs. This theory can be used to design new algorithms for inverse problems. Our results also provide a theoretical foundation for the success of DL.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including the failure of governments to act quickly enough, the failure of the pharmaceutical industry to develop a vaccine quickly enough, and the failure of the public to comply with public health measures. One of the most prominent arguments for the latter failure is that people are unable to understand exponential growth. This argument is based on a classic psychological experiment published 45 years ago. We discuss the flaws of this experiment and show that it is not only a poor example of social psychology, but also a poor example of science.

Leprosy is a chronic disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae, which has undergone extensive reductive evolution. We sequenced the genome of a Mycobacterium lepromatosis isolate from a Mexican patient, and compared it with that of M. leprae. We found that M. lepromatosis has retained the ability to cause peripheral neuropathy, and that both bacilli have retained the ability to cause leprosy. Our findings suggest that despite their ancient separation, the two leprosy bacilli are remarkably conserved and still cause similar pathologic conditions.

Entanglement and entropy are the two main resources for quantum information processing. They are also the two main ingredients of thermodynamics, which is the science of equilibrium statistical mechanics. Therefore, the study of the evolution of entanglement and entropy is a key step toward the understanding of the emergence of thermodynamics in isolated systems. We show that the quasiparticle picture of the entanglement dynamics, complemented with integrability-based knowledge of the steady state and its excitations, leads to a complete understanding of the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain. Our work opens the door to the study of the entanglement dynamics in a wide class of interacting systems. It also paves the way to the study of the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit for interacting systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global health emergency that requires a rapid response to combat the disease. Here, we describe the development of a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine candidate, which is currently in clinical development. The vaccine candidate is based on a segment of the viral spike protein recoded with synonymous suboptimal codons, thereby introducing 283 silent mutations. The vaccine candidate was shown to be highly protective in hamsters, and the vaccine candidate and its variants were shown to be temperature sensitive in vitro. This study provides a proof-of-concept for the development of a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine candidate, which can be used in mass vaccination programs. (Show more)

Plague, caused by the bacterium Yersinia pestis, is one of the deadliest diseases in human history. The Second Pandemic (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. We developed a compartmental model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. Using Bayesian inference, we found that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for pneumonic or rodent transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study provides a new perspective on the history of plague and its vectors.

The evolution of brain size has been a major focus of research in the field of comparative neurobiology. However, to understand the evolution of brain power, we need to look at the number of neurons in the brain, not at its mass. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the evolution of brain neuron numbers in amniotes, from the earliest diverging groups to the present day. We show that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. This study provides a more complete picture of the evolution of brain size and number in amniotes and has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

TRAP1 is a mitochondrial molecular chaperone that is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal cells is not well understood. Here, we show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings.

Actin filaments are the main building blocks of the cytoskeleton, and their disassembly is essential for many cellular processes. Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a key regulator of actin filament disassembly. However, how ADF regulates the disassembly of actin filaments is not fully understood. Here, we show that ADF binds to actin filaments and that this binding is enhanced by a mechanical torque. We propose that this mechanism is critical for ADF to efficiently disassemble highly connected filament networks, such as those found in cells. Our findings provide a mechanistic explanation for the role of ADF in the disassembly of actin filaments and in the regulation of cell shape. They also suggest a new approach for the design of drugs that target ADF. This work provides a general mechanism for the action of ADF, which can be applied to other proteins that bind to filaments under mechanical stress.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in soft drinks and other foods. This study shows that fructose ingestion relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the mechanisms of obesity and the effects of sugar-sweetened beverages on the brain and behavior.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, and we found that the island was settled by multiple waves of people, with a recent admixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement was not homogeneous, and that the settlement of Madagascar from Africa and Asia was not simultaneous. In addition, we found that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a comprehensive view of the history of Madagascar, and it is a first step toward a better understanding of the human history of the Indian Ocean. (Show more)

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions of others on Facebook. This is a form of emotional contagion, in which people experience the same emotions without their awareness. We show that this occurs even when people are not interacting in person, and that it is not due to the influence of in-person interaction or nonverbal cues. This work suggests that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions of others, and that in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion. This work also suggests that people’s positive emotions are not always positive, and that observing others’ positive experiences can be a positive experience for people. These results have implications for the design of social networks, and for the study of emotional contagion in the real world. (Show more)

Messenger RNAs (mRNAs) are the primary source of information for protein synthesis. The presence of mRNA modifications can have a profound impact on protein synthesis, but the consequences of the ribosome encountering mRNA modifications are not well understood. Here, we show that the presence of a common modification, pseudouridine (Ψ), in the mRNA sequence can alter the rate of protein synthesis. We also show that Ψ can promote the synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence. These findings suggest that the presence of mRNA modifications can have a profound impact on protein synthesis. This study provides a foundation for understanding the impact of mRNA modifications on protein synthesis. (Show more)

This study shows that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health and social relationships. This study also shows that this feeling is associated with positive outcomes even when controlling for factors such as socioeconomic status, depressive symptoms, and health. This suggests that the feeling of worthwhile activity may be a key factor in promoting healthy aging.

The evolution of body size in mammals is a central question in biology. We show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving the evolution of larger body sizes in four of the five extant aquatic mammal lineages. This result is consistent with the hypothesis that aquatic mammals are driven to larger body sizes by the energetic demands of the aquatic medium.

The common cold is one of the most common and economically devastating diseases in the world. The rhinovirus is the leading cause of the common cold, and the ability of this virus to replicate more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature is a major contributor to the severity of the common cold. This study demonstrates that the mouse-adapted rhinovirus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature, in part, due to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. These findings have implications for the development of therapeutics for the common cold. (Show more)

Bacteria are constantly exposed to their environment, and must be able to sense and respond to changes in the environment. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa can sense the mechanical activity of its major surface adhesin, type IV pili, and use this information to regulate its virulence. This is an example of a mechanochemical system, where the mechanical activity of a protein is used to regulate the activity of another protein. This system is important for the pathogenicity of P. aeruginosa, as it allows the bacterium to sense the mechanical activity of its surface adhesin and respond accordingly. This is an example of how bacteria can use their surface adhesin to sense and respond to their environment.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the past decades. However, the impact of pesticides on the environment is still poorly understood. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the impact of pesticides on the environment. We show that the use of pesticides is having a negative impact on the environment and that the use of newer-generation pesticides is having a greater impact. This study also shows that the use of pesticides is having a negative impact on the environment and that the use of newer-generation pesticides is having a greater impact.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human society, and the discovery of SARS-CoV-2 in animals has raised concerns about the persistence of the virus in wildlife. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer, and the discovery of multiple human lineages in deer. Our findings suggest that SARS-CoV-2 is likely to persist in deer, and that the virus may be circulating in deer populations in the United States and elsewhere. This study highlights the need for a comprehensive “One Health” approach to study the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. (Show more)

The world is moving toward a low-carbon economy, and hydropower is the leading source of renewable energy. However, the proliferation of large dams in the developing world is not sustainable. This paper examines the problems of building large dams in the developing world, including the disruption of river ecology, deforestation, loss of biodiversity, greenhouse gas emissions, displacement of people, and changes in the food system, water quality, and agriculture. We also propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) protein is the primary pathological hallmark of the disease. However, the mechanisms that lead to Aβ accumulation and the subsequent development of AD are not fully understood. Here, we show that soluble Aβ species are toxic to neurons, and that the accumulation of Aβ in the brain is a major driver of the neuroinflammatory response. This study provides a new perspective on the role of the immune system in AD, and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies.

Chickens are one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. However, the earliest evidence for their economic exploitation is still unknown. Here we present a detailed analysis of the faunal assemblage from the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, which demonstrates that the exploitation of chickens for economic purposes was widespread in the Southern Levant during the fourth–second centuries B.C.E. We also show that the adoption of chickens in European husbandry predates the introduction of this species in the Southern Levant by at least a century. Our results provide new insights into the history of the domestication and economic exploitation of chickens. (Show more)

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be a mechanism for regulating gene expression in bacteria. However, the mechanism by which this occurs is not well understood. Here, we show that the decapping enzyme responsible for removing the cap from Np4-capped RNAs is also capable of removing the cap from transcripts that are not capped. This enzyme, which is normally inactivated by stress, is capable of removing the cap in the presence of stress, and we propose that this is a mechanism for regulating gene expression in response to stress.

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality. The mechanisms involved in the development of immunosuppression during sepsis are not fully understood. Here, we show that arginine, a key amino acid, is a key player in the development of immunosuppression during sepsis. We also show that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is a promising therapeutic agent to restore immune function during sepsis. Our results suggest that citrulline could be a promising therapeutic agent for the treatment of sepsis.

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the biomass of animals is mainly concentrated in the ocean. We also highlight the historical impact of humans on the biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and its distribution among the kingdoms of life. They are a key input for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a fascinating phenomenon in nature and in physics, where a system evolves in time toward a critical state, in which the system’s activity is constant. SOC systems are characterized by a power-law distribution of activity levels, and the dynamics of the system are described by a critical equation. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a tropical model with self-organized criticality (SOC) behavior. Our model is continuous, in contrast to all known models of SOC, and is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is also a promising material for quantum applications. However, its electronic structure is sensitive to strain, and it is unclear whether it can be metallized, solely under mechanical strain without phonon instability. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly in a wide range of strain space, and we identify the pathway to metallization. We also explore phonon-instability conditions that promote phase transition to graphite. Our findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. This work is expected to be a milestone in the field of diamond science and technology. (Show more)

The study of the structure and function of peptides is a rapidly developing field. Here, we report the structure of a unique peptide, which is highly dynamic and largely disordered. We also report the antifungal activity of this peptide against plant fungal pathogens. This work provides a foundation for the development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes. In this study, we provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome. We show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm is dynamic and that the proteome of the female reproductive tract is also dynamic. We also show that the proteome of the female reproductive tract is enriched with proteins that support sperm viability. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. The protein von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a critical component of the blood clotting system. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). The A1 domain in VWF binds to platelet glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) on the surface of platelets. We show that force application switches the A1 domain to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism is important for the pathophysiology of VWD. The conversion of single molecule kon (s−1) to bulk phase kon (s−1M−1) and the kon and koff values extrapolated to zero force for the low-force pathways show remarkably good agreement with bulk-phase measurements. This suggests that the A1 domain is in a conformational state that is accessible to the bulk phase. This is a significant advance in our understanding of the role of force in the regulation of biological systems. (Show more)

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been the focus of intense study for the past decade. However, the role of viruses in human health has been more difficult to study, in part because of the lack of a comprehensive database for human-associated viruses. This study provides a comprehensive database for human-associated viruses, which is used to identify previously unknown associations between viruses and disease. The database is also used to provide a more complete picture of the human virome. This study is a significant step toward understanding the role of viruses in human health.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, the complexity of ACI makes it difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the lack of observational capability to measure the aerosol–cloud interaction processes. Here, we introduce a new instrument, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to measure aerosol and cloud properties simultaneously. This instrument is expected to be a significant contribution to the understanding of ACI. The observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a topic of interest for many years. The temperature of the surface is important for understanding the origin and evolution of life, as well as for the study of the Earth’s interior. The temperature of the surface is also important for the interpretation of the isotopic record of the oceans. This record has been the subject of much debate, and the temperature of the surface inferred from the isotopic record has been questioned. Here, we present a method for determining the temperature of the surface based on the thermostability of ancestral enzymes. The results presented here are consistent with a surface temperature that decreased over geological time.

Ion channels are the main ion-conducting proteins in cells and are important for the normal function of cells and tissues. Ion channels are also the main targets of drugs. Ion channels are composed of protein subunits, and the pore gates of ion channels are the main targets of drugs. Ion channels are also the main targets of toxins and viruses. Ion channels are the main targets of many diseases, and ion channel dysfunction is the main cause of many diseases. Ion channels are the main targets of many therapeutic drugs, and the development of new drugs is the main focus of modern drug research.

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with 207 million cases and 445,000 deaths in 2015. The parasite, Plasmodium, uses a variety of mechanisms to invade the red blood cell (RBC) and cause disease. Here, we show that the malaria parasite uses a single protein, erythrocyte binding antigen 175 (EBA175), to bind to glycophorin A (GPA) on the RBC surface. We show that this interaction alters the biophysical properties of the RBC, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This is a major change in our understanding of malaria parasite invasion, suggesting that the parasite and host cell are working together to facilitate entry. This work provides a new perspective on the malaria parasite invasion process and opens up a new area of research into the role of host cell biophysical properties in disease pathogenesis. Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality in humans. In this study, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity increases susceptibility to severe influenza virus infection. We also show that this effect is independent of viral burden and is due to impaired host defense and tissue repair. Our results suggest that low humidity may be a risk factor for influenza virus infection in humans. This study also provides a mechanistic understanding of the impact of dry air on host defense and tissue repair, which may be useful for the development of therapeutic strategies to combat influenza virus infection. The brain’s processing of language is often described as a tree, with words at the leaves and phrases at the branches. However, the brain’s activity during the construction of such structures is unknown. Here, we show that the brain’s activity during the construction of phrases is not only similar to the structure of the phrase itself, but also that of the sentence. This suggests that the brain may be using a merge operation to build phrases from words. Our results provide initial evidence for a neural implementation of a bottom-up or left-corner parser of the incoming language stream.

Axin is a key component of the Wnt signaling pathway, which is important for development and homeostasis. Axin is a large protein that has two functionally similar but distinct isoforms, Axin1 and Axin2. We show here that the two isoforms are regulated differently at the transcriptional and proteostatic level, which confers differential responsiveness to the pathway. This differential regulation may be important for the fine-tuning of the pathway.

The brain circuit that promotes overeating is not well understood. Here we present a characterization of the brain circuit that promotes overeating in mice. We show that stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus induces eating in sated mice, and that this effect is mediated by a specific group of neurons. We also show that this circuit is not involved in the regulation of hunger or satiety, and that it is not involved in the regulation of body weight. Thus, this circuit may contribute to obesity by promoting overeating. This circuit may be a target for the development of new therapeutic strategies for obesity.

This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work also provides a proof of principle for the use of rhizopine as a synthetic signal for the control of nitrogen fixation in a plant-bacterial system. The Amazon is in the midst of a rapid deforestation trend, and the causes and consequences of this trend are the subject of intense debate. This study documents the impact of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon, which was designed to reduce deforestation by providing early alerts to communities and training and incentivizing community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced deforestation, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Hearing is a fundamental sense of many animals, including all mammals, birds, some reptiles, amphibians, fish, and arthropods. The auditory organs of these animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet they are all made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the bodies of animals. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. We find that the wispy, wheel-shaped orb web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to capture the sound-induced air particle movements that approach the maximum physical efficiency better than the acoustic responsivity of all previously known eardrums. By sensing the motion of web threads, the spider remotely detects and localizes the source of an incoming airborne acoustic wave, such as those emitted by approaching prey or predators. We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C. We also demonstrate that aerosols mask the anthropogenic rise in global temperature, and that removing anthropogenic particles liberates 0.51(±0.03) °C and all pollution particles 0.73(±0.03) °C warming.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to cause suffering and death, and the need for vaccines remains urgent. We report the design and synthesis of a variant of the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the spike protein of SARS-CoV-2, which mediates viral entry to cells. This variant exhibits enhanced immunogenicity and cross-reactivity with variants of concern, and presentation of the variant on a virus-like particle reduces weight loss in hamsters. These results suggest that the variant may be a promising candidate for a vaccine or a component of a vaccine.

The role of ALK in the development of human tissues is well established. Here, we show that the ALK family of receptors is also involved in the development of the zebrafish pigment cells. We demonstrate that the zebrafish ALK homologs are involved in the development of the pigment cells and that the ligands are secreted proteins. Our results provide evidence for the involvement of the ALK family of receptors in the development of human tissues. This is an important finding, as it suggests that the ALK family of receptors is involved in the development of a wide range of tissues.

The emergence of plague, a disease that has plagued humanity for millennia, is a complex process that has been difficult to reconstruct. We present a large dataset of ancient Yersinia pestis genomes from Eurasia, which allowed us to explore the diversity of this pathogen during the formative years of its emergence. Our results suggest that the emergence of plague was a gradual process, with a single lineage persisting for thousands of years. We also discovered the presence of a flea-adapted form of plague in Bronze Age Iberia, which suggests a much wider geographic spread of this form of plague. These data provide a more complete picture of the formative years of plague’s evolution and ecology. (Show more)

This work examined the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 presidential election and Joe Biden in the 2020 presidential election. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted support for Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support.

Soil organic carbon (SOC) sequestration in agricultural systems is a critical strategy for mitigating climate change. However, the management of annual cropping systems on grassland-derived Mollisols is a major source of uncertainty in this effort. We show that soil health management practices that increase soil organic matter, such as reduced tillage, cover crops, and manure addition, can increase SOC storage in annual cropping systems on Mollisols. However, these practices do not increase the amount of carbon stored in the most stable fraction of SOC, mineral-associated organic matter. This finding highlights the importance of soil health management practices that increase the amount of carbon stored in the most stable fraction of SOC. These practices can be combined with the restoration of perennial grasslands and rotational grazing to sequester large amounts of carbon on Mollisols. This approach can help to mitigate climate change and improve soil health.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a more comprehensive approach to identifying and prioritizing the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We developed a framework to identify risk factors associated with spillover of viruses from animals to humans, and used this to rank the risk of 887 wildlife viruses. We validated the framework using data from 509,721 samples from 74,635 animals, and demonstrated the utility of the framework in identifying the risk of new viruses. The SpillOver platform is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. SpillOver is a tool that can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to animals for pollination. The color of nectar is an important trait that attracts animals, but the chemical basis for this trait is poorly understood. Here, we show that the red color of nectar is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify a previously unknown mechanism for the production of this pigment. This work provides a molecular basis for the evolution of red nectar and demonstrates that a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. The history of Europe is marked by a series of migrations and invasions, which have shaped the genetic landscape of the continent. However, the processes that occurred during the period between the migrations of the Neolithic farmers and the Roman invasion are poorly understood. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a group of women from Bavaria, Germany, who lived at the time of the Roman withdrawal. Our results indicate that they had a genetic ancestry that was not present in modern Europeans, and that they differed in visible characteristics. This example of female-biased migration indicates that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a newly emerged pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how HKU4 and HKU5 transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. Our results suggest that MERS-CoV, but not HKU4, has adapted to use human cells for cross-species transmission. These results also suggest that bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmission. Thus, the receptor usage and host range of the virus-surface spike proteins of bat coronaviruses are important determinants for their potential to cause human infections. (Show more)

The ability to rapidly identify the cause of undifferentiated febrile illness is critical to the early detection and control of epidemics. We demonstrate that metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) is a feasible, cost-effective, and scalable approach for pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens, including chikungunya virus, which presaged a national outbreak. Our findings highlight the importance of mNGS in the early detection of emerging pathogens and the need for coordinated pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings. This approach can be used to identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. The human genome is replicated in a complex process that requires the concerted action of multiple proteins. One of the most important proteins involved in the replication of the lagging strand is proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA). PCNA is a sliding clamp that is responsible for the replication of the lagging strand template. In this study, we show that the human pol δ is not bound to PCNA during DNA synthesis. This finding has profound implications for the replication of the lagging strand as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This study provides a unique perspective on the role of PCNA in the replication of the lagging strand. (Show more)

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in science. In this work, we report the first in vitro evolution of an RNA polymerase ribozyme, which can replicate RNA from an RNA template. This work represents a major step toward the reconstruction of RNA-based life, as it allows the replication of genetic information in the absence of proteins.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to study the physical dynamics of five US cities. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that the physical appearance of neighborhoods may be a key factor in the distribution of economic opportunity.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but also a toxic metal that can cause damage to cells. The existence of a copper-binding fungal natural product is a significant discovery, as it suggests that fungi have evolved a mechanism to control the cellular copper content. This study demonstrates that the xan BGC-derived isocyanide products of the xan biosynthetic gene cluster have the ability to bind copper and impact cellular copper content. The ability of xan BGC products to bind copper and impact cellular copper content is demonstrated in a variety of pathogenic fungi and bacteria. The existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. This study provides a foundation for further investigation of the role of fungal natural products in copper homeostasis and the impact of copper on fungal interactions with other microbes. Frost is a major environmental factor that affects the performance of plants and animals across the world’s temperate and boreal zones. Despite their ecological and economic impact on agriculture and forestry, the geographic distribution and evolutionary impact of these frost events are poorly understood. We show that the geographic distribution of frost risk is changing in the Northern Hemisphere, and that this change is driven by the evolutionary history of the species. Our findings can inform decision-making in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory response in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the developmental pathways that give rise to these cells are not well understood. Here, we show that the development of Th17 cells is contingent on the expression of both Stat4 and T-bet, but not the IL-12 or IFN-γ receptors. Moreover, we show that Th17 cells can provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. This plasticity may be important for the development of disease in inflammatory bowel disease.

The disease is caused by mutations in several genes, but the mechanisms are unknown. Here, we report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients with ALS, which can be used to study the disease and screen for drugs to treat it. This method will be useful for studying the mechanisms of the disease and for developing new therapies. This method will also be useful for studying other neurodegenerative diseases, such as Alzheimer’s disease. The role of the microbiota in the transmission of infectious agents to vectors is an emerging area of research. Here, we show that the tick-borne bacterium Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces the expression of antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the gut microbiota and enhances the ability of the bacterium to colonize the vector. We also show that the protein binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall of bacteria, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These findings provide insight into the mechanisms by which a human pathogen exploits an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. The study of the origin of the avian tail and the evolution of the avian tail-bone (pygostyle) is critical for understanding the origin of the modern avian bauplan. Here, we describe a basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis, and show that it represents the second earliest diverging group of the Pygostylia. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases the known ecomorphological diversity of basal pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding mosaic evolution in early birds.

We show that the water vapor in the stratosphere plays an important role in the climate system. This is because the water vapor in the stratosphere is sensitive to changes in temperature, and this sensitivity is large enough to make it a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity.

Chlorosis is a phenomenon in which vertebrates have unusually high concentrations of biliverdin, a pigment that is normally found in the blood. This study describes the biochemical and molecular basis of chlorosis in anurans, and shows that the phenomenon has evolved multiple times during the evolutionary history of this group. We also show that the biliverdin-binding serpins (BBSs) are responsible for the green color of the animals, and that they are most similar to human alpha-1-antitrypsin. Our results provide a molecular and functional basis for chlorosis, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily. This study also provides a molecular and functional basis for chlorosis, and introduces a function for a member of the serpin superfamily.

Hypoxia is a feature of many cancers, and the ability of cancer cells to survive in hypoxic environments is a key factor in the development of metastases. In this study, we show that hypoxia induces expression of ALKBH5, an m6A demethylase, which in turn increases the proportion of breast cancer cells that have the cancer stem cell phenotype. This is achieved by increasing the levels of NANOG, a gene that encodes a pluripotency factor. Thus, ALKBH5 may be a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer.

The Bible was the first book to be printed, and the first printed books were pocket Bibles. The parchment used to make these books was a major innovation in the history of book production. The source of this parchment, however, has been a long-standing controversy. Here, we report the results of a study of 465 parchment samples, including 72 pocket Bibles, that demonstrate that the source of the parchment used to make the first pocket Bibles was not the use of fetal calves or sheep, as has been suggested, but rather the use of maturing animals of several species.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The cause of the extinction is uncertain, but the evidence points to a combination of factors. The age model for the extinction is critical to understanding the timing of the trigger and kill mechanisms. The age model presented here provides a precise age for the onset of the extinction and a precise age for the recovery of the biota.

Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a chronic inflammatory disease of the gastrointestinal tract, which is characterized by the presence of immune complexes and the activation of the immune system. IBD is a complex disease, and the underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. Here, we report that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) plays an important role in the pathogenesis of IBD. We found that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORαΔIEC mice exhibit excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Our study provides a potential therapeutic target for IBD. (Show more)

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. We use cryo-electron microscopy to compare the structure of the spike protein in two variants that are currently circulating. We find that the D614G mutation leads to a more open conformation of the spike, which may facilitate binding to the receptor and subsequent fusion. This study provides a structural basis for the increased infectivity of the D614G mutant virus. (Show more)

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that the pandemic has resulted in a decline in life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y, lower than any year since 2003. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites, would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006.

The chemical properties of an atom are the basis of all chemistry. The chemical potential of an electron is a fundamental property of an atom, and it is the driving force of chemical reactions. We show that the chemical potential of an electron is a useful property to describe the chemical properties of an atom. We also show that the chemical potential of an electron is a fundamental property of an atom, and it is the driving force of chemical reactions.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and intensity of extreme weather events, including wildfires. However, the effects of climate change on fire activity are uncertain, and the role of human ignitions is poorly understood. We show that changes in human demography, rather than climate, are the main driver of changes in fire activity over the last century. This has led to a reduction in fire activity, which has offset some of the warming caused by human emissions. However, the risk of more extreme fires is high, and the effects of climate change on fire activity are likely to be more important in the future.

The provision of nutrients to specific symbiotic microbes is a widespread strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is the cue that triggers the maturation of the symbiotic organ of the squid Euprymna scolopes. This glycan is provided in a cyclic manner, and its catabolism is required for the maintenance of the symbiont population and the periodic acidification of the symbiotic organ. These results suggest that the provision of specific nutrients may be a general mechanism used by animals to control the activities of their associated microbes. This study also provides a model for the study of the regulation of the activities of symbiotic microbes in animals. (Show more)

Text data are ubiquitous and are increasingly being used to understand the world around us. However, the complexity of text data makes it difficult to identify patterns in them. We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data and represent documents as topic sequences. Our method is based on advances in machine learning and can be applied to a wide range of domains. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. We believe that this method will be useful to researchers in many fields.

The second plague pandemic, which started with the arrival of Yersinia pestis in Europe in the mid-14th century, lasted for four centuries. This period is often explained as the consequence of a single introduction of the bacterium, after which it established itself in European rodents. However, we show that the climate conditions in Asia, where the bacterium originated, were favorable for the reintroduction of Y. pestis into Europe on multiple occasions. Our results suggest that the bacterium was not permanently established in Europe, but was reintroduced on a regular basis.

Asteroids are a diverse group of invertebrates that are abundant in the Northeast Pacific Ocean. In recent years, a number of asteroid species have experienced mass mortality events, which have been linked to a densovirus. Here, we provide evidence that the virus is the cause of the disease and that it has been present on the North American Pacific Coast for at least 72 y. This is the first report of a densovirus in asteroids and the first report of a disease caused by a densovirus in this group of invertebrates.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia in adults, and the prognosis is poor. There is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies for AML, ideally targeting the disease at its stem cell origin. We show here that monoclonal antibodies targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) are effective in the treatment of AML in mice. We also show that the antibody can achieve both antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. Furthermore, the results suggest that the IL1RAP antibody could be used in combination with other agents to treat AML. This approach could be applied to other targets of interest for the treatment of AML. (Show more)

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, and we found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The settlement history of Madagascar is also unique, with a recent and sex-biased colonization from Africa and Asia. Finally, we show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations.

The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants has led to the development of new variants of concern (VOCs) that have shown increased transmissibility and immune evasion. Crop experts are the primary source of information on the status of crops in the field. However, their assessments are subjective and qualitative, and thus difficult to use in quantitative analyses. We demonstrate that this index is more accurate than official forecasts released midseason, and can be used to monitor crop status and predict crop yields.
